conclusion: Initial state A: $T_A = -73°C = 200$ K (converting to Kelvin)
Process: A → B → C (as shown in the p-V diagram)
Change in internal energy from A to C: $\Delta U_{A→C} = 200$ J
Standard conditions: 1 mole occupies 22.4 L at 1 atm and 273 K

premise: Using the ideal gas law at state A: $pV = nRT$
conclusion: Amount of gas in moles $n = \frac{3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \times 1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3}{8.314 \text{ J/(mol·K)} \times 200 \text{ K}} = 0.1804$ mol
For an ideal gas, the change in internal energy depends only on temperature: $\Delta U = nC_V \Delta T$
For an ideal monatomic gas, $C_V = \frac{3}{2}R$; For an ideal diatomic gas, $C_V = \frac{5}{2}R$; For an ideal polyatomic gas, $C_V = 3R$
Number of particles = $n \times N_A = 0.1804 \text{ mol} \times 6.0 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1} = 1.082 \times 10^{23}$ particles

premise: Using $\Delta U = nC_V \Delta T$ for monatomic gas
